entries.summary: Many participants are questioning whether to join the Women’s March this weekend after several of the group’s national organizers have been accused of anti-Semitism and bigotry. However, there are still plenty of activists and a few organizations, like Planned Parenthood, who say they will show up to support the march and its leaders. So can the core movement that was born out of reactionary resistance to President Trump survive the infighting and controversy it has endured over the past year? entries.summary: The British Parliament has yet to agree on how exactly they should leave the European Union. If they don’t reach a consensus, then the U.K. could be set for a "hard Brexit" at the end of March—meaning they leave the European Union without any deal in place to manage the exit. entries.summary: One prominent Democratic donor. Two mysterious deaths. And a host of unanswered questions. Ed Buck, who has donated to the campaigns of Hillary Clinton, Congressman Ted Lieu and Senator Kyrsten Sinema, is facing increased scrutiny after two gay black men were found dead in Buck’s home in the past 18 months. A cause of death hasn’t been released for the second man but authorities say the first man, Gemmel Moore, died of an accidental overdose. Signal speaks to Los Angeles based journalist Jasmyne Cannick about the clues Moore might have left behind before he died.

entries.summary: In Reviving Detroit Part 1.1, Detroit was once the richest city in the U.S. And after decades of decline, Detroit now is among the most poverty-stricken. In this piece, we look at the history of the city to explain how it got here.
entries.title: How Detroit went from a booming metropolis to a shrinking city

mpscall.title: How Detroit went from a booming metropolis to a shrinking city

entries.summary: In Reviving Detroit Part 1.2, residents and experts debate if the city can bounce back. Detroit’s population is at nearly a quarter of what it was at its peak. And despite a recent wave of gentrification in Detroit’s downtown and midtown neighborhoods, the city is still struggling with rampant crime, a failing school system and swaths of vacant land with tens-of-thousands of blighted homes.
entries.title: Can Detroit rise from decades of decline?

mpscall.title: Can Detroit rise from decades of decline?

entries.summary: In Reviving Detroit Part 2.1, Detroit Public Schools rank the lowest in the country. Decades of corruption and mismanagement — coupled with overall economic decline in the region — has left the district with more than 195 closed campuses and students ranking dead last in the nation for math and reading. Despite decrepit school buildings and limited resources, district leadership and educators are hoping to create change.
entries.title: Is there hope for Detroit Public Schools?

mpscall.title: Is there hope for Detroit Public Schools?

entries.summary: In Reviving Detroit Part 2.2, at a school where majority of students come from low-income households, the faculty dedicates its time and personal resources to ensure a safe, positive experience for their students every day. In a poverty-stricken community and a school district with limited funding, the Young Coleman A. Elementary School is attempting to beat the odds.
entries.title: This Detroit public school is attempting to beat tough odds

mpscall.title: This Detroit public school is attempting to beat tough odds

entries.summary: In Reviving Detroit Part 3.1, visit Detroit’s east side, which for years was punctuated by swaths of vacant land, blighted homes and leftover industrial squalor. Now, vacant lots are teeming with rows of growing saplings, thanks to the efforts of Hantz Woodlands.
entries.title: How an abandoned Detroit neighborhood found higher purpose

mpscall.title: How an abandoned Detroit neighborhood found higher purpose

entries.summary: In Reviving Detroit Part 3.2, hundreds of public structures have been demolished on Detroit’s east side, making way for 25,000 trees. Hantz Woodlands is working to revitalize 140 acres in the community by converting its vacant parcels into tree nurseries with hopes of creating livable neighborhoods.
entries.title: This tree farm is bringing life back to Detroit’s east side

mpscall.title: This tree farm is bringing life back to Detroit’s east side

entries.summary: In Part 4.1 of Reviving Detroit, as the city bounces back, local law enforcement is making strides to create safer communities. The city of Detroit has the second highest rate of violent crime in the United States. If there’s any hope for investment and industry to return, reducing drug and violent crime is crucial for the city’s rebirth.
entries.title: How Detroit law enforcement combats crime in a city plagued with violence

mpscall.title: How Detroit law enforcement combats crime in a city plagued with violence

entries.summary: In Part 4.2 of Reviving Detroit, the Detroit Police Department takes a hard line on crime. An enhanced city-wide security camera system and a new Neighborhood Police Officer program are two ways the Detroit Police Department is attempting to revitalize a city that has allowed crime to thrive for years.
entries.title: Creating a safer Detroit for communities to grow

mpscall.title: Creating a safer Detroit for communities to grow

entries.summary: Part 5.1 of Reviving Detroit looks at the city’s widespread blight problem. Once-flourishing neighborhoods are now full of abandoned homes. In 2014, 78,000 structures were deemed abandoned, many of them now breeding grounds for crime. Can the city restore its historic neighborhoods?
entries.title: Can Detroit’s abandoned communities rise from ruin?

mpscall.title: Can Detroit’s abandoned communities rise from ruin?

entries.summary:
How Detroit is fighting blight
In Part 5.2 of Reviving Detroit, a federal grant now funds the salvaging, demolition or auction of abandoned properties. Blighted neighborhoods are being cleared out, creating the potential for renewal. But what happens when the money runs out?
entries.title: How Detroit is fighting blight

mpscall.title: How Detroit is fighting blight

entries.summary: In Reviving Detroit Part 6.1, we visit an urban farm that is providing work for convicted felons. After serving time on felony charges, it’s near impossible to find work. RecoveryPark Farms provides job opportunities for returning citizens and recovering addicts, teaching farming techniques to keep men and women employed while they rebuild their lives.

entries.summary: In Reviving Detroit Part 6.2, we return to RecoveryPark. After acquiring 105 acres from the Detroit Land Bank, RecoveryPark plans to expand its farming footprint across the city. entries.title: Detroit’s RecoveryPark is changing lives for the better

Schwartz also comments on Trump calling Michael Cohen a “rat”, telling Melber Trump “loves violence”.

Cohen's friend, Donny Deutsch, who spoke to him shortly after his testimony tells Ari Melber about Cohen's response to the hearing.
